_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Pursuant to the Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, Section 112(r), this Risk Management 
Plan (RMP) document addresses the risk management plan for the Fresno Cogeneration Partners 
(FCP) facility located near San Joaquin, Fresno County, California.  This RMP also includes 
all the elements of Process Safety Management (PSM) as required by the Occupational Health 
and Safety Administration (OSHA).  The FCP facility which is owned by Fresno Cogeneration 
Partners, L.P., and operated by WSI Services, Inc. (WSI), is in the business of power 
production and uses anhydrous ammonia (Chemical Abstract Service [CAS] #7664-41-7) a 
regulated substance, and aqueous ammonia (CAS #1336-21-6) also a regulated substance.  This 
RMP document has been prepared in accordance with the California Accidental Release 
Prevention (CalARP) Program Guidance Document dated June 8, 2004 (California Code of 
Regulations [CCR], Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5).  The PSM section has been prepared 
in accordance with Title 8 of the California Code of Regulations Section 5189.  

The FCP plant processes and stores ammonia in quantities above the Federal and State 
regulatory threshold quantities and therefore, is submitting this RMP.  A Program 3 RMP is 
being submitted due to the proximity of the facility to off site receptors.


1.1    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

WSI has an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that is used to respond to emergency situations.  
The plan consists of reporting and notification, mitigation, evacuation, emergency response 
assistance, and medical assistance procedures.  These procedures are discussed in detail in 
Section 7 of this report.

1.2    The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The primary activity at the FCP facility is to generate electricity for sale.  The facility 
is located in a rural part of Fresno County and includes a 55 megawatt (MW) cogeneration 
unit (Cogeneration Unit) and a 2

3 MW simple-cycle peaking gas turbine unit (Peaking Unit).  
The Cogeneration Unit is driven by a 45-MW General Electric LM6000 stationary combustion gas 
turbine (CGT).  The Peaking Unit is driven by a 23 MW Pratt and Whitney FT4A9 gas turbine.  
The Cogeneration Unit is equipped with a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system to control 
emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOX) by injecting anhydrous ammonia (NH3) into the exhaust gas 
stream upstream of a catalyst.  The anhydrous ammonia is stored onsite in a 12,000 gallon 
aboveground pressure vessel.  The maximum operating capacity of the vessel is 9,984 liquid 
gallons (56,800 pounds) with a heel volume of 216 gallons and a vapor space of 1,800 gallons. 
From the vessel, ammonia vapor is injected into an air stream for injection into the SCR grid.
The Peaking Unit is in simple-cycle configuration exhausting through an oxidation catalyst 
and a selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system to control emissions of NOX by injecting a 
19% solution of aqueous ammonia (NH4OH).  The aqueous ammonia is stored onsite in a 7000 
gallon aboveground vertical tank at atmospheric pressure. 

1.3    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

WSI is dedicated to operating a safe facility.  WSI employees are trained in every aspect 
of hazardous materials management, from using personal protective equipment (PPE) to 
performing maintenance on facility equipment.  All employees are trained in emergency 
evacuation procedures.  A written program for maintaining and inspecting the ongoing 
integrity of all regulated substance process equipment ensures that equipment receives 
appropriate, regularly scheduled maintenance.  Regular inspections document and identify 
the condition and reliability of each piece of equipment.  Maintenance on all tanks containing 
ammonia is performed weekly (unless otherwise stated) and consists of visual inspection and 
preventive maintenance activities.  General tan

k condition is inspected and maintenance 
performed when deemed necessary.  Changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and 
procedures will be implemented when necessary.  Before a process change occurs, management 
of change protocol will be implemented to ensure a safe and smooth transition.

WSI performs a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) for the ammonia tanks and for any modification 
significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.  The pre-startup 
safety review shall confirm that, prior to the introduction of regulated substances, the 
process conforms to all specified regulations and safety requirements.

WSI shall also report any events that may lead to impacts onsite or offsite, regardless of 
whether or not an actual impact does occur, according to the incident investigation program 
contained herein.

1.4    Five-year Accident History

WSI has an excellent safety record.  There have not been any accidental releases of anhydrous 
ammonia nor aqueous ammonia within the last five years that resulted in death, injury, or 
significant property damage on site, or known offsite death, injury, evacuation, sheltering 
in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

1.5    Worst-Case Release Scenarios and Alternative Release Scenarios

Cogeneration Unit

For the anhydrous ammonia storage tank, the worst-case release scenario assumes a rupture of 
the tank, resulting in a constant release of the entire contents into the air for duration of 
10 minutes.  This scenario results in the toxic endpoint distance of 4.4 miles from the tank.  
The alternative release scenario, which is considered a plausible event, assumes a release of 
about 200 gallons into the air for a duration of 1 minute.  The alternative release scenario 
results in a distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.5 miles.  The toxic endpoint is the 
theoretical distance from the source where the concentration could result in harm if the 
exposure occurred in excess of a one-ho

ur period.  For anhydrous ammonia, the toxic endpoint 
concentration is 0.14 milligrams per liter (mg/L).

Peaking Unit

For the aqueous ammonia storage tank, the worst-case release scenario assumes a rupture of the 
tank, resulting in a constant release of the entire contents.  This scenario results in the 
toxic endpoint distance of 1.3 miles from the tank.  The alternative release scenario, which 
is considered a plausible event, assumes a release of about 100 gallons into the air for a 
duration of 1 minute.  The alternative release scenario results in a distance to the toxic 
endpoint of 0.1 miles.  The toxic endpoint is the theoretical distance from the source where 
the concentration could result in harm if the exposure occurred in excess of a one-hour period.  For aqueous ammonia, the toxic endpoint concentration is 0.14 mg/L.

1.6    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

WSI recognizes that an effective risk management program involves continuous improvement and 
is committed to providing a safe environment for its employees, customers, and the surrounding 
area.  Improvements are implemented when possible to support this commitment.  These 
improvements may include upgrading equipment maintenance procedures, training requirements, 
operating procedures, or system controls.  When possible, a less hazardous substance will be 
substituted for a chemical currently used in the process.
Prior to implementing any changes to these chemical systems, WSI employees will follow written 
Management of Change procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, 
procedures, and facilities.  These written procedures address the following issues:

A?    Technical basis for the proposed change(s)
A?    Impact of the proposed change(s) on health, safety, and environment
A?    Modification of the operating procedures
A?    Implementation schedule for the proposed change(s)
A?    Authorization for the proposed change(s)

Employees involved with affected processes will be info

rmed and trained in the changes as 
early as practicable prior to startup of the process involved.  Written operating procedures 
will be updated as needed.

When nonconformance conditions are identified, WSI takes the following measures: 

A?    Shutdown of processes and operations.
A?    Collecting and containing released waste.
A?    Removing or isolating containers.
A?    Monitoring for leaks, ruptures, etc.
A?    Ensuring sufficient temporary storage of generated wastes.
A?    Arranging for repair or replacement of affected system areas.

WSI has not identified any equipment, process, or management change that will be implemented 
for this process.
